captions.text:
Good morning, John. In your last video, you
were able to quite successfully point out

that Ima Hogg and Harry Baals were able to
overcome the poor decision-making skills of

their parents and become successful people
despite their ridiculous names.

And maybe Chris P Bacon would never have become
a successful composer if it weren't for his

ridiculous name, but... you know, it's kind
of the job of a parent to, uh, help a child

avoid unnecessary anguish. And let's be honest,
a bad name can be a source of significant
anguish.

So for all of you future parents and, most
importantly, your children, this is my guide
to how to name your baby properly.

First: Say it out loud. Say it out loud in
every possible permutation. And you might
want to run it by a focus group of 12-year-olds.

Like, Andrew Peacock's parents never knew,
and neither did poor Drew, until that day

in fourth grade... this is starting to sound
like a limerick.
Anyway, punchline: Droopycock.

It could have been avoided with a focus group
of 12-year-olds saying it out loud.

Second: Name your child what you will call
your child. This has been a problem for me

my entire life. I am Hank; I have always been
Hank. My whole life, my parents called me
Hank, but they named me William.

So whenever I'm at a doctor's office or at
the airport, and somebody asks me what my

name is, I sit there thinking for a second.
And I feel like a doof because this person

has just asked me what my name is, and I should
know what my name is, and they're hastily
adding me to the suspicious flyer list.

Third: If you do not speak the language where
your child will grow up, get some native language-speakers
to come in and help you.

Maybe the world wouldn't really be a better
place if there were fewer Harry Dongs out

there, but it probably would be a better place
for those Harry Dongs.

Fourth: Stop trying to be cute. I know your
name is Silva and you think it's adorable

to name your daughter "Sterling" and your
son "Hi-Ho". And I'm in this group, too; my

last name is Green and I think it'd be adorable
to have a daughter named Olive Green.

But just don't do it, because some day, Hi-Ho
Silva is going to be an adolescent and you

don't want him to have another reason to hate
you.

Five: Check for the top baby names... and
avoid them.

Names, though you might have forgotten this
in all of the excitement, have a utilitarian

purpose. They are a unique identifier that
you place upon a person so that that person

can know when people are talking to or about
that person.

If your child has the same name as 10% of
the people in their social group, I have news
for you: You have failed.

And don't just assume that if you avoid John
and Jennifer, you're all good. Lemme tell

ya, those names aren't even in the top 10
anymore. The two top baby names of 2010 were

Jacob and Isabella, and there were more Jaydens
than there were Johns.
Six: Spell like a normal person.

I don't understand why parents do this! It
doesn't change anything, it just means that

in the future, you will have to spell your
name every time anyone wants to write down
your name.

Do not name your child Mykul [Michael], or
Kayt [Kate], or Jaucshuwa [Joshua], or Quathyryn
[Katherine]!

Seventh and last rule: Name your child a freaking
name.

Do not name your child after a comic book
character, or an item of clothing, or a profession,

or — most importantly — do not name it
after some virtue that they will enjoy all

too much rebelling against in their early
teens, like Chastity.

Okay, and this is the actual final rule: There
are no rules. Let's be honest, Harry Baals

and Ima Hogg prove that you are not your name
and it doesn't really matter.

A bad name really probably won't lead to anything
except a little bit of extra adolescent angst.

And let's be honest, adolescents are gonna
find their angst somewhere; they might as
well find it in their name.
John, I will see you tomorrow.

Endscreen. I just got my immunizations from
Haiti. The one is Bugs Bunny and the other
is Scooby Doo.

Ow! I'm going to be in Haiti in, like, a week's
time, which means that I'm going to be in

Miami in less than a week's time, so if you've
not bought your tickets, you should. It's

very possible that we won't have any for sale
at the door, so you should definitely buy
in advance.

title: How to Name Your Baby Properly

comments.text:
I also find it weird when parents name their child a childish diminutive 
officially. Like yeah I know you're never going to call Theodore "Theodore" 
when he's a baby but does he really need to be stuck with "Teddy" on his 
passport when he's 60?﻿
comments.author: TigsAndKizzii

comments.text:
My parents thought about naming me Katherine or Katrina or Katharina after 
my great-grandmother, but they didn't want me to be a Katie because there 
were a lot of young children named Katie while my mom was pregnant with me. 
So, they really tried. But there has never been a year when I didn't have 
at least one classmate named Sarah, for as far back as I can remember.﻿
comments.author: Sarah

comments.text: my name is the original catherine﻿
comments.author: bookfandomfab

comments.text:
My name is Lili Delicious.... DELICIOUS.. my mum did not foresee then 
getting married to a man with the surname White. Lili Delicious White.﻿
comments.author: Lili D

comments.text:
One of my favorite musicians is a Canadian electro-pop/indie artist named 
LIGHTS. Her real name is Valerie, but she actually got it legally changed 
to Lights, as this was her nickname growing up and more people called her 
that anyway. It fits, actually. She is one of the most buoyant, brightest, 
and happiest people and it really reflects her music.

Now she recently had a baby a couple of years ago, and she named her 
daughter "Rocket". Some people criticized her for this, but the origins 
behind the name are beautiful. I think that both of their names are 
beautiful.

Though, I agree with Hank in that you should be very careful when you name 
your child. Choose something unique, but not TOO unique.

Also, if anyone here is a LIGHTS fan, I would love to hear. She's awesome 
and the rest of you should listen to her. She's been called the Canadian, 
female Owl City.﻿
comments.author: RyanX1231

comments.text: +RyanX1231 What were the origins behind the name?

comments.text:
I wish my parents would've been more creative when naming me and my 
sisters. Christina (yes, I spell it differently to make it at least 
somewhat different), Elizabeth, and Mikayla. I went to school with a girl 
who had, not only the same first name, but same middle name, too (Marie, 
which I possibly hate even more than my first name). My name is just so 
boring. I wish I had something more different and unique, but because 
neither of my parents have a creative bone in their body, I'm stuck. At 
least my sisters both have some sort of meaning behind their names. They 
were both named after family, blah blah blah. I was named after a f**king 
doll. Ugh.﻿

comments.text:
Sometime around the 2000's, the name Gabriele ( but not spelled Gabrielle) 
became very popular in Lithuania. When I was in school there were two more 
Gabriele's, so to lessen the confusion, our teacher used to have to call me 
Big Gabriele. Even my auntie wanted to name her daughter that, but had to 
settle for Gabija instead because I was born first (hehe).

In England, thank God, that's not the case. But Fatimas we have here 
galore, and i'd guess we have six of them in my year alone. It's a pretty 
name too, but people just can't resist cracking fat jokes around these 
girls.﻿
comments.author: Gabriele Banyte

comments.text:
Yes my parents called me Darcy, but not like the normal ways of spelling it 
: Darcy / Darcey or anything of that matter. No my name is spelt : d'Arcy 
.... Yes I don't have a capital letter at the start of my name ( by the 
way, for the record is the worst thing in the world as autocorrect and 
every single person on this earth spells it : D'Arcy, which must I add is 
extremely annoying, and I always have to correct them (and on my school ID, 
Passport, and my Health Records is spelt that way, because my dad was so 
smart by spelling it that way on my birth certificate... he uses the excuse 
that he was extremely nervous??) but my Mum and Dad now tell me that it was 
spelt wrong on the certificate. And my mum wanted to spell it this way as 
she went to Art College and I think she believes that it is all 
"expression" and "difference" etc, and she wanted it to be "French" ... So 
yes, my name is Darcy but spelt in a wierd French self expressed form of 
the English Language. ﻿
comments.author: d'Arcy Connor

How I'm going to name my future kids, after my favorite fictional 
characters. However I will limit myself to one name from each fandom for 
one gender. Also I won't name my kids after a ship but half, for example if 
I have a son and name him Percy and then have a daughter I'm NOT naming her 
Annabeth. This will continue until my spouse and I literally overuse my 
uterus and it is biologically dangerous to have anymore children. My future 
husband will be damned if he tries to stop me but he can pick middle names.﻿

comments.text:
If I ever have a son, I kind of really want to name him Percy. I've always 
liked the name Percy. I also want to have his middle name be Sirius, only 
because if someone tells him to stop goofing around and be serious then he 
can say, "Well, Sirius is my middle name."
*UPDATE* I realise now that my ideal name for a son would be Percy *Sirius 
Dragg*. Serious Dragg. I can see it now. Kids saying, "C'mon Percy, don't 
be such a dragg! Yeah, you don't have to be serious all the time!" I guess 
it's a good thing that my name isn't really Zach Dragg.﻿

weren't).﻿

comments.author: Lilly K.

comments.text:
I had three requirements for naming my two daughters.  The names had to be 
historically significant, invoke an image of power and be extremely 
uncommon.  Both my girls are very proud of their names, in large part 
because there is a story behind both of them, but also because of what the 
name invokes.  I remember telling one person where I got one of the names 
from and I told her the story.  I then asked her why she named her child 
what she did, and she said, "I just liked the name".  ﻿
comments.author: highdough

I quoted from was his first comment, and the one that started this.
comments.author: highdough

comments.text: +highdough Ah, so you did read his comment! C: you liar.
comments.author: pink3puppy

comments.text:
+pink3puppy This is what he said....

"Your kids probably only like their names because you brainwashed them to 
think that they are good. Now all you have to do it wait for them to be 
bullied because of it and they won't like their names as much"

He claimed I have brainwashed my children, that they will hate their names 
and that they will be bullied because of what I named them.  

And you don't think I should be offended by that?  Really?
comments.author: highdough

comments.text:
+highdough I read his entire comment. TL;DR version is thus:

Quit getting offended. No one is trying to insult you, rather it has 
nothing to do with you. Quit putting yourself on such a high pedestal. no 
one is attacking your babies' names. Let alone do we care about them. (We 
don't. Really, we don't.) The point of the video was to talk about names in 
general. Not YOUR name or YOUR BABIES' names. 


TL;DR of said short paragraph above. (I know reading is hard some times :c )


*NOBODY CARES.*


Think I got the gist of it? Or was I just putting my own feelings into it.. 
hmm..
comments.author: pink3puppy

comments.text:
+sheepcanfly4 I will admit I didn't read your entire comment because it 
seemed like a long pointless rant, but if the guy keeps responding to me, 
that's really his own doing.  If I don't want to argue with someone, then I 
don't.  I don't keep replying.  

And he started off attacking me for a completely innocuous comment that was 
directed at no one.  I simply responded in kind.  

And yes, his initial comment was an attack.
comments.author: highdough

comments.text:
+highdough   what part of i dont want to argue any more do you not 
understand? you seem to want to continue arguing with him even tho he 
clearly is trying to back out of this pointless argument.

the way you responded to Sciex's reply sounded a lot like you were 
attacking him. if you think about it correctly and actually use your brain 
you can see that it isnt an insult but instead him pointing out a negative 
thing about uncommon names, and with personal experience the comment may 
differ due to a sightly emotional response.

"It seems to me that you are so upset with your own name so much so that 
you put your own frustrations onto everyone else.  Not everyone is like 
you." this really reminds me of how bullies put other people down.... using 
something they feel bad about against them in an argument.

also btw it's just their name its not a big deal, being proud about your 
name is just a ridiculous. wow you are named after a great person, or your 
name means something and its very rare, it doesnt matter. A name is just a 
name, its how to address someone, and it has nothing to due with who you 
are, or how special you are. you dont specifically need to name your 
children after something special, you chose something that you like the 
sound of. choosing names based on the rarity and meaning kinda shows points 
towards someone believe that giving their child a name like that would make 
them better.

feel free if you want to reply to this, i just came here to point out an 
error that you made, and to attempt to show you how rude you have been. the 
amount of effort you put into defending your children's names, and 
attacking someone is just ridiculous, and im surprised that you would be 
doing this rather than spending time with your family or doing something 
productive. now if you dont mind now im going to do something with my time 
and spend the rest of tonight talking to my boy friend, who i couldn't care 
less about what his damn name is.
comments.author: sheepcanfly4

comments.text:
+highdough Please point out, without insulting me, how I apparently 
insulted you other than my initial comment.
comments.author: Sciexful

comments.text:
+Sciexful If you're going to apologize for insulting me (and you did insult 
me with your initial comment), maybe don't throw in other insults at the 
same time.  Maybe there's a reason you were bullied, and it wasn't because 
of your name.  It's because you seem to lack a few social graces.
comments.author: highdough

comments.text:
+highdough I'm not sure if these are your daughters but here are the names 
I have: Boudicca, Lilith and Chloe (however, you only mentioned 2 
daughters). Stating that I judged them by their name is ridiculous on 
account of according to you I don't know their name. I only knew that 
according to you they were uncommon, on that basis I gave my view about 
uncommon names in regard to a scientific theory. (I did not mean to state 
that they would be bullied, only that they would be more likely to be 
bullied).

Your latest response is ridiculous btw, you didn't need to attack me or 
draw conclusions. I simply stated a scientific theory.

"And considering how common unique names are, nowadays, your complaints 
seem rather outdated, quite frankly"
This sentence means nothing. Again, The theory is what I'm talking about. 
As for the logic of your sentence. Uncommon names have almost always 
existed as they have to do with statistics. There are quite allot of 
parents who want their kids to have unique names, and there are those that 
want to name them after someone famous or someone they are related to. This 
is a reason as to why some names are more common that others. Some simply 
become more popular and appealing.

And your statement did not "set me off". The apology was because from your 
response and looking back at what I said; I may of said it in a threatening 
way when I didn't mean it. The reason I mentioned your statement is because 
it was very questionable and I doubted it. 

Anyway to finish this off, I don't want to argue. I'm too weak for that and 
again, I'm sorry if I have insulted you.
comments.author: Sciexful

comments.text:
+Sciexful I understand the implications of names, but you literally have 
absolutely no idea WHAT I named my children, but seemed to have come to the 
conclusion that I've made a huge mistake that will haunt them forever.

It seems you are doing your best to uphold the tradition of judging people 
by their names.  Ironic, isn't it?

As for how I know my children are proud of their name, it's not even a 
question. I'm not going to list the reasons why I know by they are many. 
 And they are plenty old enough.  

It seems to me that you are so upset with your own name so much so that you 
put your own frustrations onto everyone else.  Not everyone is like you.  

And the fact that my statement that my kids are proud of their name set you 
off so much is far more telling of your issues, because apparently you 
can't comprehend a world where people might be proud of a unique name.  

I have a common name, but have never liked it, which is one reason I wanted 
a unique name with my kids.  And considering how common unique names are, 
nowadays, your complaints seem rather outdated, quite frankly. 

You obviously have issues with your name, but don't take it out on everyone 
else.
comments.author: highdough

comments.text:
+highdough I know it's not your fault, I was never blaming you. I'm just 
stating that a person names can affect the outcome of their life. 
http://www.businessinsider.com.au/how-your-name-affects-your-success-2014-8 
There have been various studies about how names affect people. Weather you 
realise it or not there is bias in everyday life and people judge people by 
their name. Teachers do this, consciously or not. It can affect your rate 
of employment and how well you do academically.

I was not implying that names with stories behind them lead to bullying, I 
was however trying to say that people with uncommon names are more likely 
to be bullied and have low self esteem. I'm sorry for lashing out at you, 
and the reason for doing so was partly because I dislike the idea of people 
giving their kids uncommon names as well as your statement "Both my girls 
are very proud of their names". How would you know if they are proud of 
their names? did they tell you? how old are they? Or are you just putting 
words into their mouth? The reason I responded as I did is because it's the 
exact same thing my parents did. They tried to make me proud of my name and 
it's apparent significance and to me it has only been a curse (mostly 
because it's a religious name which no one seems to pronounce correctly). 
I'm unsure as to weather your statement is true of if it is a delusion to 
justify your choice. (otherwise known as a proud parent)
comments.author: Sciexful

comments.text:
+Sciexful So because you don't like your name and were apparently bullied 
because of it, you then assume ALL people with names with stories behind 
them are going to hate their name and be bullied?

Well, the problem is not the name but the people.  We live in an apparently 
more enlightened neighbourhood where there is almost no bullying and lots 
of kids have unique names.  Neither of my children have ever been made fun 
of for their name, and no "brainwashing" was needed.

Quite frankly, you sound quite young, and it's not my fault you don't like 
your name.
comments.author: highdough

comments.text:
You know what, my parents did the exact same thing an have the exact same 
story, I hate my name. Your kids probably only like their names because you 
brainwashed them to think that they are good. Now all you have to do it 
wait for them to be bullied because of it and they won't like their names 
as much (people with uncommon names get bullied more and have lower self 
esteem). If you talk to someone about what you named your kids it's likely 
that they will say something like "that's a cool name" because they don't 
want to be rude. In that situation it's not like you can say "that's a 
horrible name, it sucks"
comments.author: Sciexful

comments.text:
THANK YOU! My mom named me out of a popular baby book with unique spelling 
and it made my school life awful. And then they all wonder why I changed 
it.﻿
comments.author: Fallendemona

comments.text:
Is it really that uncommon to not go by your first name in America? I've 
got three given names, as it were, and I go by my middle name, Klara. It's 
never been an issue with...well, anything. All three names are on my 
ID-card and in my passport, and if they need my personal identity number 
(sort of like social security number), they usually ask witch name I go by.﻿
comments.author: Red Apprentice

comments.text: +Catie F Ah, I see. Thank you so much :) DFTBA
comments.author: Red Apprentice

comments.text:
People in the US don't typically have more than one first name. So it is 
not unheard of, especially if the first name is deemed common. Also it 
could be based on the parents' preference. My grandparents decided to call 
my mother by her middle name. A shorten nickname for me which helped since 
there were other girls with my legal name in my class.
